title: Lab 3: ANOVA
text:
Today’s Lab Overview
Duration: 2 hours
Dataset: Experimental Data (n=150)
What we’ll do:

One-way ANOVA
Post-hoc comparisons
Effect sizes (eta-squared)
Two-way ANOVA (factorial designs)

title: Lab 3: ANOVA
text:
When to Use ANOVA
t-test: Compare 2 groups
ANOVA: Compare 3+ groups
Why not multiple t-tests? - Inflates Type I error rate - ANOVA controls family-wise error

title: Lab 3: ANOVA
text:
Part 1: One-Way ANOVA
Time: 30 minutes
Compare three or more groups:
# Fit the model
model <- aov(score ~ condition, data = mydata)

# View results
summary(model)

title: Lab 3: ANOVA
text:
Reading ANOVA Output
            Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value  Pr(>F)
condition    2   1250   625.0   12.5  0.0001 ***
Residuals   97   4850    50.0
Key values: - F-statistic - p-value - Degrees of freedom

title: Lab 3: ANOVA
text:
Part 2: Post-Hoc Tests
Time: 30 minutes
Which groups differ?
# Tukey's HSD
TukeyHSD(model)

# Or pairwise t-tests with correction
pairwise.t.test(data$score, data$condition,
                p.adjust.method = "bonferroni")

title: Lab 3: ANOVA
text:
Part 3: Effect Sizes
Time: 30 minutes
Calculate eta-squared:
library(effectsize)
eta_squared(model)



η² value
Interpretation




0.01
Small


0.06
Medium


0.14
Large

title: Lab 3: ANOVA
text:
Part 4: Two-Way ANOVA
Time: 30 minutes
Factorial designs with two IVs:
model <- aov(score ~ factor_a * factor_b, data = mydata)
summary(model)
Tests: - Main effect of A - Main effect of B - A × B interaction

title: Lab 3: ANOVA
text:
Interpreting Interactions
When the effect of one IV depends on the level of another:
# Visualise the interaction
interaction.plot(data$factor_a, data$factor_b, data$score)

# Or with ggplot2
ggplot(data, aes(x = factor_a, y = score, colour = factor_b)) +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "line", aes(group = factor_b))

title: Lab 3: ANOVA
text:
APA Reporting

A one-way ANOVA revealed a significant effect of condition on scores, F(2, 97) = 12.50, p < .001, η² = .21.


Post-hoc comparisons using Tukey’s HSD indicated that…

text:
What is R?
R is a programming language designed for statistics and data analysis.

Free and open source - anyone can use it
Created by statisticians, for statisticians
Thousands of packages for specialised analyses
The standard in psychology, biology, and social sciences
Produces publication-ready figures and tables

title: Lab 1: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Why R (not SPSS)?



R
SPSS




Free forever
Expensive licence


Code is reproducible
Point-and-click is hard to repeat


Cutting-edge methods
Lags behind


Used in academia & industry
Mainly academia


Shareable scripts
Hard to share workflows




Learning R is an investment in your future career.

title: Lab 1: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Why Reverse Score?
Some questionnaire items are negatively worded:

“I rarely feel anxious” (reversed)
“I often feel anxious” (normal)

If someone is anxious, they’d score low on the first but high on the second.

To create a valid total score, we must reverse the negatively-worded items.

title: Lab 1: Descriptive Statistics
text:
The Formula
For a 1-5 Likert scale:
\[\text{reversed} = 6 - \text{original}\]



Original
Reversed

3

2


5
1

title: Lab 1: Descriptive Statistics
section: Common Error: Wrong Items in Sum
text:
Common Error: Wrong Items in Sum

# WRONG - using unreversed items!
data$pers_score <- data$p1 + data$p2 + data$p3 +
                   data$p4 + data$p5


Fix: Always use reversed versions:

# CORRECT
data$pers_score <- data$p1 + data$p2 + data$p3 +
                   data$rev_p4 + data$rev_p5

Following the intervention, the control group showed [minimal change / a decrease / an increase] (M = , SD = ), whereas the training group showed [change description] (M = , SD = ).

title: Lab 1: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Example Write-Up

Participants reported moderate levels of personality overall (M = 15.42, SD = 2.31). At baseline, the control group (M = 15.10, SD = 2.25, n = 40) and training group (M = 15.33, SD = 2.18, n = 40) were similar. Following the intervention, the control group showed minimal change (M = 15.28, SD = 2.41), whereas the training group showed an increase (M = 16.95, SD = 2.15).

title: GoldPsychR Pedagogical Approach
text:
This document describes the pedagogical approach behind GoldPsychR, designed to lower instructor effort, increase student engagement, and build genuine R fluency through multiple learning cycles.


Students learn best through repeated exposure with varied contexts. Rather than showing something once, we expose students to the same concepts through multiple modalities:

Watch - See code demonstrated with explanation
Try - Experiment with interactive code in the browser
Apply - Use the skills on real data in RStudio
Transfer - Practice again with a different dataset
Reference - Look up patterns when needed later




Our key innovation is embedding mini slide decks directly into practice pages. Students see:

A short slide presentation (5-10 slides) explaining one concept
Interactive WebR cells to practice immediately
Self-assessment questions to check understanding
A download button for the RStudio exercise

Benefits:

Students only need 2 browser tabs (our page + RStudio Server)
Slides and practice are spatially co-located - no context switching
Each “Part” is a complete learning cycle in ~15 minutes
Instructors can walk around helping rather than presenting

Each lab is divided into 5 Parts, each covering one coherent skill:

title: GoldPsychR Pedagogical Approach

3.1 Two Tabs, Full Workflow
Students open:

GoldPsychR page - embedded slides + WebR practice

title: GoldPsychR Pedagogical Approach
text:
3.2 Self-Paced with Built-in Checkpoints
Each Part includes:

A countdown timer suggesting time allocation
Self-assessment questions that provide immediate feedback
Challenge prompts to extend learning
A download button for the RStudio exercise

title: GoldPsychR Pedagogical Approach
text:
3.3 Progressive Scaffolding Removal

Part 1: Full code provided, just run and observe
Part 2: Some blanks to fill in
Part 3: More blanks, hints available
Part 4: Minimal scaffolding
Part 5: Write your own code from scratch

title: GoldPsychR Pedagogical Approach
text:
4.1 Reduced Live Presentation
Instead of presenting for 45 minutes straight:

Students watch short embedded slides at their own pace
You circulate and help individuals
Class time becomes active learning time

title: GoldPsychR Pedagogical Approach
text:
4.2 Consistent Materials Across Modalities
The same code examples appear in:

The embedded slides
The WebR practice cells
The RStudio exercise template
The follow-on exercise

One update propagates everywhere.

title: GoldPsychR Pedagogical Approach
text:
4.3 Self-Checking Reduces Support Burden
Quiz questions catch common misconceptions:

“What does <- mean?” → answered by quiz
“Why do I get NA?” → answered by quiz
“Did I use the reversed items?” → answered by quiz

You focus on conceptual help, not syntax questions.

title: Lab 1: Descriptive Statistics
text:
In this lab, you’ll learn to analyse Big Five personality data in R. We’ll work through loading data, scoring questionnaires, calculating descriptives, creating visualisations, and writing up results.


We’ve collected personality data from a training study:

160 participants completed personality questionnaires
Half received a training intervention, half were controls
Measured before (pre) and after (post) the intervention

Our research question: Did the training affect personality scores?



By the end of this lab, you will be able to:

Navigate RStudio and understand its four panes
Load CSV data into R using read_csv()
Reverse-score negatively worded questionnaire items
Calculate descriptive statistics by group using dplyr
Create boxplots using ggplot2
Write an APA-style results paragraph

title: GoldPsychR
text:
Welcome
This is the course hub for PS51020A R Labs, a 4-week intensive programme teaching R for psychological research at Goldsmiths, University of London.






TipGetting Started



If this is your first time here:

Access the RStudio Server and check you can login correctly
You need to use your @campus.goldsmiths.ac.uk username, such as jbond007@campus.goldsmiths.ac.uk
All datasets used in this course are available to download from the VLE or the internet





Course Schedule
Each week follows the same learning pathway:
Slides → WebR Practice → Exercise → Follow-On



Week
Topic
Resources




1
Descriptive Statistics
Slides • WebR • Exercise • Follow-On


2
Comparing Groups (t-tests)
Slides • WebR • Exercise • Follow-On


3
ANOVA
Slides • WebR • Exercise • Follow-On


4
Correlation & Regression
Slides • WebR • Exercise • Follow-On





Learning Pathway
Key techniques are taught in a research context through three core stages:



Stage 1: Instructor Demo
Watch & Learn
Live demonstration of R skills with real psychology data



Stage 2: WebR Practice
Try in Browser
Interactive practice with instant feedback - no installation needed



Stage 3: Exercise
Work in RStudio
Apply skills independently and submit your work



Additional Resources:

Follow-On Exercises - Extra practice with different datasets to consolidate learning
R Toolbox - Reference guide organised by skill for quick lookup



Quick Links


Learning Materials

Lab Materials - Full lab worksheets
WebR Practice - Interactive browser-based R
Follow-On Exercises - Transfer practice



Reference

R Toolbox - Code reference by topic
R Handbook - Comprehensive guide
Troubleshooting - Common errors & fixes





What You’ll Learn
By the end of this programme, you will be able to:

Load, inspect, and clean data in R
Calculate descriptive statistics and reverse-score questionnaire items
Create publication-quality visualisations with ggplot2
Compare two groups using independent and paired t-tests
Compare multiple groups using one-way and factorial ANOVA
Run correlation and simple regression analyses
Calculate and interpret effect sizes (Cohen’s d, eta-squared, R²)
Write APA-style results sections
Use Quarto for reproducible reports



Support






NoteNeed Help?




During labs: Ask your instructor or demonstrators
Between labs: Post on the course discussion forum
Technical issues: Check the Troubleshooting Guide
Bug reports: Report an issue on GitHub




Course Lead: Gordon Wright | Email: gordon@littlemonkeylab.com

title: explain these answers demo
text:
For the next set of chapters we’re going to use data from the most popular model of personality, the Big Five.

First, take part in this online version of the Big-5. It only takes a few minutes to complete and it used the items from Soto and John (2017) which a short-form version of the Big Five Inventory 2 (BFI-2).

Second, read the textbook chapter on personality trait theorists.
Finally, answer the following questions. Please note that your responses will not save in the browser - if you want to save them, make a note of them somewhere.



The trait ‘Agreeableness’ in the Big Five personality model refers to:

 The tendency to be organized, careful, and disciplined The tendency to be compassionate, cooperative, and warm towards others The tendency to be outgoing, energetic, and sociable The tendency to experience mood swings, anxiety, and irritability.




In the context of the Big Five Personality model, which trait might be associated with a person who is diligent, efficient, and follows a schedule?


 Neuroticism Conscientiousness Extraversion Agreeableness



Individuals who are often nervous, insecure, and easily upset, are considered to have high  according to the Big Five Personality Model.



In the Big Five Personality Model, people who are outgoing, sociable, and assertive score high on the trait known as 



Which of these traits in the Big Five Personality model is most closely associated with creativity and a preference for novelty?

 Extraversion Conscientiousness Neuroticism Openness to Experience




Explain these answers


The correct answer is “The tendency to be compassionate, cooperative, and warm towards others”. Agreeableness as a personality trait characterizes individuals who are friendly, compassionate, and like working with others. They tend to be more cooperative while interacting with others.
The correct answer is “Conscientiousness”. This trait is associated with people who are organized, responsible, and prefer planned rather than spontaneous behavior. High conscientiousness means a person is disciplined, efficient, and diligent.
Neuroticism is a personality trait in the Big Five Model. High neuroticism often means a person is likely to experience feelings such as anxiety, anger, or depression. These individuals are more likely to interpret ordinary situations as threatening and minor frustrations as hopelessly difficult.
Extraversion characterizes individuals who are outgoing, sociable, and often possess high group visibility. They like to talk, assert themselves, and draw attention to themselves.
The correct answer is “Openness to Experience”. Individuals with high openness are often very creative, curious about their surroundings, and more aware of their feelings. They tend to think and act in individualistic and non-conforming ways and are likely to have a broad range of interests.

title: Embedding Slides in Documents
text:
Tips for Embedding

Use relative paths - ../slides/filename.html from the demos folder
Set a reasonable height - 500-600px works well for most screens
Add allowfullscreen - lets users expand the slides
Consider mobile - the 16:9 responsive method scales better
Add borders - helps distinguish the embed from page content

title: Lab 3: ANOVA
text:
2.1 t-test vs ANOVA

t-test: Compare 2 groups
ANOVA: Compare 3+ groups

Why not just run multiple t-tests?






WarningMultiple Comparisons Problem



Running many t-tests inflates your Type I error rate. ANOVA controls this!








NoteSelf-Check



When should you use ANOVA instead of a t-test?
AlwaysWhen comparing 2 groupsWhen comparing 3 or more groups

title: Lab 1: Descriptive Statistics
text:
The Data Story
We’ve collected personality data from a training study:

160 participants completed personality questionnaires
Half received a training intervention, half were controls
Measured before (pre) and after (post) the intervention

Our research question: Did the training affect personality scores?

TipExample Write-Up





Participants reported moderate levels of personality overall (M = 15.42, SD = 2.31). At baseline (pre), the control group (M = 15.10, SD = 2.25, n = 40) and training group (M = 15.33, SD = 2.18, n = 40) were similar. Following the intervention (post), the control group showed minimal change (M = 15.28, SD = 2.41, n = 40), whereas the training group showed an increase (M = 16.95, SD = 2.15, n = 40). These descriptive patterns suggest a potential training effect.

title: Part 1: What is R?
text:
The Data Story
Over the next 4 weeks, we’ll work through a complete research workflow:

Week 1: Describe and visualise your data
Week 2: Compare groups with t-tests
Week 3: Compare multiple groups with ANOVA
Week 4: Explore relationships with correlation & regression

title: Part 1: What is R?
text:
Today’s Dataset
We’ve collected Big Five personality data from a training study:

160 participants completed personality questionnaires
Half received a training intervention, half were controls
Measured before (pre) and after (post) the intervention

Our question: Did the training affect personality scores?

title: Part 1: What is R?
text:
What is R?
R is a programming language designed for statistics and data analysis.

Free and open source - anyone can use it
Created by statisticians, for statisticians
Thousands of packages for specialised analyses
The standard in psychology, biology, and social sciences

title: Part 1: What is R?
text:
Why R (not SPSS)?



R
SPSS




Free forever
Expensive licence


Code is reproducible
Point-and-click is hard to repeat


Cutting-edge methods
Lags behind


Used in academia & industry
Mainly academia



Learning R is an investment in your future career.

title: Part 1: What is R?
text:
RStudio: Your R Workspace
RStudio is an application that makes R easier to use.
Think of it like this:

R = the engine
RStudio = the car dashboard

You’ll work in RStudio, but R does the actual computing.

title: Part 1: What is R?
text:
The Four Panes


Top-Left: Source

Where you write scripts
Save your work here

Bottom-Left: Console

Where code runs
Immediate feedback


Top-Right: Environment

Your data and objects
Watch it update!

Bottom-Right: Files/Plots/Help

Navigate files
View outputs

title: Part 3: Reverse Scoring
text:
Why Reverse Scoring?
Questionnaires often include negatively worded items to:

Reduce response bias
Check if participants are paying attention
Balance the scale

Example:

Positive: “I am the life of the party”
Negative: “I don’t like to draw attention to myself”

title: Part 3: Reverse Scoring
text:
The Problem
If someone scores 5 (strongly agree) on both:

“I am outgoing” → High extraversion ✓
“I prefer to be alone” → High extraversion? ✗

We need to reverse the negative item before summing!

title: Part 3: Reverse Scoring
text:
The Formula
For a 1-5 scale:
\[\text{reversed} = 6 - \text{original}\]



Original
Reversed




1
5


2
4


3
3


4
2


5
1

title: Part 3: Reverse Scoring
text:
Why 6?
The formula is: (max + min) - original
For a 1-5 scale: (5 + 1) - original = 6 - original
For a 1-7 scale: (7 + 1) - original = 8 - original

title: Part 5: APA Write-Up
text:
Why APA Style?
American Psychological Association style ensures:

Consistency across publications
Easy comparison of results
Professional presentation

title: Part 5: APA Write-Up
text:
The Key Components
When reporting descriptive statistics:

M = Mean
SD = Standard Deviation
n = Sample size

Always report all three!

title: Part 5: APA Write-Up
text:
Formatting Numbers
Rules:

Round to 2 decimal places
Use M and SD in italics
Include sample sizes

Example:

M = 3.27, SD = 0.70, n = 40

title: Part 5: APA Write-Up
text:
Getting Your Numbers

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Part 5: APA Write-Up
text:
Template Structure
A good descriptive results paragraph has:

Overall description (M, SD for whole sample)
Baseline comparison (were groups similar?)
Post-intervention comparison (what changed?)
Interpretation (what does this suggest?)

title: Part 5: APA Write-Up
text:
Example Paragraph

Participants reported moderate levels of personality overall (M = 15.23, SD = 2.45). At baseline, the control group (M = 15.10, SD = 2.38, n = 40) and training group (M = 15.36, SD = 2.52, n = 40) showed similar scores. Following the intervention, the control group showed little change (M = 15.15, SD = 2.41), whereas the training group showed an increase (M = 16.89, SD = 2.21). These descriptive patterns suggest a potential training effect.

title: Part 5: APA Write-Up
text:
Common Mistakes
❌ “The mean was 3.27234567”
✓ “The mean was 3.27”
❌ “M = 3.27”
✓ “M = 3.27”
❌ “Group 1 had higher scores”
✓ “The training group (M = 16.89) had higher scores than the control group (M = 15.15)”

title: Animated Code in Revealjs
Animated Code in Revealjs
text:
How It Works
The syntax code-line-numbers: "|1-2|4|5-7|8" means:

First: show all code (no highlight)
Then: highlight lines 1-2
Then: highlight line 4
Then: highlight lines 5-7
Finally: highlight line 8

title: Animated Code in Revealjs
text:
Code Annotations (Hover)
Hover over the circled numbers to see explanations:

1penguins |>
2  filter(!is.na(bill_length_mm)) |>
3  group_by(species) |>
4  summarise(mean_bill = mean(bill_length_mm))


1

Start with the penguins dataset

2

Remove rows with missing bill lengths

3

Group the data by species

4

Calculate the mean bill length for each group

title: Animated Code in Revealjs
text:
Annotations + Progressive Highlight
Combine annotations with line highlighting:

ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species, y = bill_length_mm)) +
1  geom_boxplot(fill = "steelblue") +
2  theme_minimal() +
3  labs(
    title = "Bill Length by Species"
  )


1

Create boxplots with a nice fill colour

2

Apply a clean, minimal theme

3

Add informative labels

title: Animated Code in Revealjs
Animated Code in Revealjs
text:
Annotated dplyr Pipeline
A complete annotated example:

1data_summary <- penguins |>
2  filter(!is.na(body_mass_g)) |>
3  group_by(species, sex) |>
4  summarise(
    mean_mass = mean(body_mass_g),
    sd_mass = sd(body_mass_g),

title: Webex general
text: This set of exercises will test your knowledge about various aspects of deception in psychology. Answer the questions to check your understanding of key concepts, theories, and research findings in this area.

title: Webex general
text:
Fill-In-The-Blanks

The tendency for people to believe they are less likely to be deceived than others is known as the  to deception.
In deception research, the  is an actor who works with the experimenter to deceive the actual participant.
The  is a genuine smile that involves both the mouth and the eyes, making it harder to fake in deceptive situations.

title: Webex general
text:
Multiple Choice

Which of the following is NOT typically considered a reliable indicator of deception?

Increased blinkingReduced hand gesturesLack of eye contactIncreased speech errors

The theory that proposes that lying is more cognitively demanding than telling the truth is called:

Interpersonal Deception TheoryCognitive Load TheoryFour-Factor TheorySelf-Presentation Theory

In a typical deception study, who is usually unaware of the true nature of the experiment?

ParticipantExperimenterConfederateResearch Assistant

title: Webex general
text:
True or False

Polygraph tests are highly accurate and widely accepted in scientific communities as reliable lie detectors. TRUEFALSE
People are generally better at detecting lies told by strangers than by those close to them. TRUEFALSE
Microexpressions are brief, involuntary facial expressions that can potentially reveal concealed emotions in deceptive situations. TRUEFALSE

title: Webex general
text:
Longer MCQs
Which of the following best describes the “Truth-Default Theory” in deception research?

 The theory that humans are naturally inclined to always tell the truth The theory that humans tend to believe others are telling the truth unless given reason to think otherwise The theory that truth-telling is easier and requires less cognitive effort than lying The theory that cultural norms universally prioritize truthfulness over deception

What is the primary focus of Interpersonal Deception Theory (IDT)?

 The neurological processes involved in creating and maintaining a lie The dynamic interaction between the deceiver and the target of deception The cultural variations in perceptions and acceptance of deceptive practices The psychological motivations that drive individuals to engage in deceptive behavior

title: Webex general
text:
Checked sections

Research suggests that detecting deception is:
Easy for most peopleOnly possible with specialized trainingDifficult, with accuracy rates often only slightly above chanceImpossible without technological aids
Explain why detecting deception is challenging for most people:


Click for explanation

Detecting deception is challenging for several reasons:

Many common beliefs about deception cues (e.g., lack of eye contact) are not reliable indicators.
Liars often strategically control their behavior to appear truthful.
Individual differences in baseline behavior make it hard to identify deviations.
The cognitive load of trying to detect lies can impair judgment.
Confirmation bias can lead people to interpret ambiguous cues in line with their expectations.

title: Webex general
text:
Hidden solutions and hints
A researcher wants to study how cognitive load affects lying behavior. Describe a potential experimental design to investigate this.


I need a hint

Consider how you might manipulate cognitive load (e.g., through a secondary task) and measure lying behavior. Think about what control conditions you might need.




Click here to see a possible experimental design

Possible Experimental Design:

Participants: 100 adults randomly assigned to two groups (50 each)

Procedure:
1. All participants are asked to lie about a recent experience

2. Experimental group: 
   - Must count backwards from 100 by 7s while lying (high cognitive load)

3. Control group:
   - Simply lie without additional task (normal cognitive load)

4. Measure dependent variables:
   - Speech hesitations
   - Speech rate
   - Amount of detail provided
   - Perceived believability (rated by independent judges)

5. Compare measures between groups to assess the effect of cognitive load on lying behavior

This design allows us to isolate the effect of increased cognitive load on various aspects of lying behavior.


This set of exercises covers various aspects of deception psychology, including theories, research methods, and key findings. It utilizes different question types to engage learners and test their understanding of the subject matter.

title: R Handbook
text:
This handbook is a reference companion for your Research Methods labs. Use it to look up R code patterns when you’re working on assignments.






TipHow to Use




Search (Ctrl/Cmd + F) for what you need
Copy code examples and adapt them
Bookmark this page for quick access

title: R Handbook
text:
2.1 Assignment and Objects

# Assign a value to a variable
x <- 5
my_score <- 42

# View a variable
x
print(my_score)

# Remove a variable
rm(x)

# List all objects in environment
ls()

title: R Handbook
text:
2.2 Data Types

# Numeric
age <- 25
height <- 1.75

# Character (text)
name <- "Alice"
group <- "control"

# Logical (TRUE/FALSE)
passed <- TRUE
is_control <- FALSE

# Check type
class(age)        # "numeric"
class(name)       # "character"
class(passed)     # "logical"

title: R Handbook
text:
2.3 Vectors

# Create a vector with c()
scores <- c(4, 5, 3, 2, 5)
names <- c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol")
conditions <- c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE)

# Access elements
scores[1]         # First element: 4
scores[2:4]       # Elements 2 through 4
scores[c(1, 3)]   # Elements 1 and 3

# Useful functions
length(scores)    # Number of elements
sum(scores)       # Sum of all elements
mean(scores)      # Average
min(scores)       # Minimum
max(scores)       # Maximum

title: R Handbook
text:
2.4 Basic Operations

# Arithmetic
5 + 3     # Addition
10 - 4    # Subtraction
6 * 7     # Multiplication
20 / 4    # Division
2 ^ 3     # Exponent (2 cubed = 8)
17 %% 5   # Modulo (remainder: 2)

# Comparisons (return TRUE/FALSE)
5 > 3     # Greater than
5 < 3     # Less than
5 == 5    # Equal to
5 != 3    # Not equal to
5 >= 5    # Greater than or equal
5 <= 3    # Less than or equal

# Logical operators
TRUE & FALSE   # AND: FALSE
TRUE | FALSE   # OR: TRUE
!TRUE          # NOT: FALSE

title: R Handbook
text:
3.1 Loading Data

# From CSV (readr package - recommended)
library(readr)
data <- read_csv("filename.csv")
data <- read_csv("path/to/filename.csv")

# From CSV (base R)
data <- read.csv("filename.csv")

# From URL
data <- read_csv("https://example.com/data.csv")

# Suppress column type messages
data <- read_csv("filename.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

title: R Handbook
text:
3.2 Inspecting Data

# First/last rows
head(data)        # First 6 rows
head(data, 10)    # First 10 rows
tail(data)        # Last 6 rows

# Structure and dimensions
str(data)         # Structure with types
dim(data)         # Rows and columns
nrow(data)        # Number of rows
ncol(data)        # Number of columns

# Column names
names(data)       # All column names
colnames(data)    # Same as names()

# Summary statistics
summary(data)     # Summary of all columns

title: R Handbook
text:
3.3 Accessing Columns

# Using $ (most common)
data$age
data$group

# Using [[ ]]
data[["age"]]

# Using [ ] with column name
data[, "age"]

# Using [ ] with column number
data[, 1]         # First column
data[, 2:4]       # Columns 2 through 4

title: R Handbook
text:
3.4 Creating New Columns

# Simple calculation
data$new_column <- data$column1 + data$column2

# With conditions
data$category <- ifelse(data$score > 50, "high", "low")

# Multiple conditions
data$grade <- case_when(
  data$score >= 70 ~ "A",
  data$score >= 60 ~ "B",
  data$score >= 50 ~ "C",
  TRUE ~ "F"
)

title: R Handbook
text:
4.1 The Pipe Operator

library(dplyr)

# Pipe: |> (or %>%)
# Takes output from left, passes as first argument to right

# Without pipe
summarise(group_by(data, condition), mean = mean(score))

# With pipe (easier to read!)
data |>
  group_by(condition) |>
  summarise(mean = mean(score))

title: R Handbook
text:
4.2 Selecting Columns

# Select specific columns
data |> select(id, score, group)

# Select range of columns
data |> select(p1:p5)

# Remove columns
data |> select(-id, -notes)

# Select by pattern
data |> select(starts_with("p"))
data |> select(ends_with("score"))
data |> select(contains("time"))

title: R Handbook
text:
4.3 Filtering Rows

# Single condition
data |> filter(group == "control")
data |> filter(age > 25)

# Multiple conditions (AND)
data |> filter(group == "control", time == "pre")
data |> filter(group == "control" & time == "pre")

# Multiple conditions (OR)
data |> filter(group == "control" | group == "treatment")
data |> filter(group %in% c("control", "treatment"))

# Exclude missing values
data |> filter(!is.na(score))

title: R Handbook
text:
4.4 Creating/Modifying Columns

# Create new column
data |> mutate(total = p1 + p2 + p3)

# Modify existing column
data |> mutate(score = score / 100)

# Multiple operations
data |> mutate(
  total = p1 + p2 + p3,
  mean_score = total / 3,
  category = ifelse(total > 10, "high", "low")
)

title: R Handbook
text:
4.5 Grouping and Summarising

# Group by one variable
data |>
  group_by(condition) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n()
  )

# Group by multiple variables
data |>
  group_by(condition, time) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Count observations
data |> count(condition)
data |> count(condition, time)

title: R Handbook
text:
4.6 Arranging (Sorting)

# Sort ascending
data |> arrange(score)

# Sort descending
data |> arrange(desc(score))

# Sort by multiple columns
data |> arrange(group, desc(score))

title: R Handbook
text:
5.1 Central Tendency

# Mean
mean(data$score)
mean(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)  # Ignore missing values

# Median
median(data$score)
median(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Mode (no built-in function)
names(sort(table(data$category), decreasing = TRUE))[1]

title: R Handbook
text:
5.2 Variability

# Standard deviation
sd(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Variance
var(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Range
range(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
min(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
max(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Interquartile range
IQR(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

title: R Handbook
text:
5.3 Other Useful Statistics

# Sum
sum(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Length/count
length(data$score)
n_distinct(data$id)  # Unique values (dplyr)

# Quantiles
quantile(data$score, probs = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75), na.rm = TRUE)

# Comprehensive summary
summary(data$score)

title: R Handbook
text:
6.1 Reverse Scoring

# For 1-5 scale: reversed = 6 - original
data$rev_item <- 6 - data$item

# For 1-7 scale: reversed = 8 - original
data$rev_item <- 8 - data$item

# For 0-4 scale: reversed = 4 - original
data$rev_item <- 4 - data$item

# General formula: reversed = (max + min) - original
# For 1-5: max + min = 6, so 6 - original

title: R Handbook
text:
6.2 Creating Scale Scores

# Sum score
data$total <- data$item1 + data$item2 + data$item3 + 
              data$rev_item4 + data$rev_item5

# Using rowSums (more efficient)
data$total <- rowSums(data[, c("item1", "item2", "item3", 
                                "rev_item4", "rev_item5")],
                      na.rm = TRUE)

# Mean score
data$mean_score <- rowMeans(data[, c("item1", "item2", "item3",
                                      "rev_item4", "rev_item5")],
                            na.rm = TRUE)

title: R Handbook
text:
7.1 Basic Structure

library(ggplot2)

# Basic template
ggplot(data, aes(x = variable1, y = variable2)) +
  geom_XXXXX() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Title", x = "X Label", y = "Y Label")

title: R Handbook
text:
7.2 Histogram

# Basic histogram
ggplot(data, aes(x = score)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30)

# Styled histogram
ggplot(data, aes(x = score)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, fill = "#4A90A4", colour = "white") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Scores", x = "Score", y = "Count")

# Histogram by group
ggplot(data, aes(x = score, fill = group)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, alpha = 0.6, position = "identity") +
  theme_minimal()

title: R Handbook
text:
7.3 Boxplot

# Basic boxplot
ggplot(data, aes(x = group, y = score)) +
  geom_boxplot()

# With fill colour
ggplot(data, aes(x = group, y = score, fill = group)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7)

# Grouped by two variables
ggplot(data, aes(x = group, y = score, fill = time)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Scores by Group and Time",
       x = "Group", y = "Score", fill = "Time")

title: R Handbook
text:
7.4 Bar Chart

# Counts
ggplot(data, aes(x = group)) +
  geom_bar()

# From summary data (means)
ggplot(summary_data, aes(x = group, y = mean)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#4A90A4") +
  theme_minimal()

# With error bars
ggplot(summary_data, aes(x = group, y = mean)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#4A90A4", alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = mean - se, ymax = mean + se), 
                width = 0.2) +
  theme_minimal()

title: R Handbook
text:
7.5 Scatterplot

# Basic scatterplot
ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = score)) +
  geom_point()

# With regression line
ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = score)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE) +
  theme_minimal()

# Coloured by group
ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = score, colour = group)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  theme_minimal()

title: R Handbook
text:
7.6 Customisation

# Themes
+ theme_minimal()
+ theme_classic()
+ theme_bw()

# Labels
+ labs(
    title = "Main Title",
    subtitle = "Subtitle",
    caption = "Data source",
    x = "X-axis Label",
    y = "Y-axis Label",
    fill = "Legend Title",
    colour = "Legend Title"
  )

# Colours
+ scale_fill_manual(values = c("control" = "#E8E8E8", 
                                "treatment" = "#4A90A4"))
+ scale_colour_manual(values = c("pre" = "#B8D4E3", 
                                  "post" = "#4A90A4"))

# Axis limits
+ xlim(0, 100)
+ ylim(0, 50)
+ coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 100), ylim = c(0, 50))

title: R Handbook
text:
8.1 Object not found

# Error: object 'x' not found

# CAUSE: Variable does not exist
# FIX: Create it first, or check spelling

x <- 5  # Create the object
x       # Now it works

title: R Handbook
text:
8.2 Could not find function

# Error: could not find function "read_csv"

# CAUSE: Package not loaded
# FIX: Load the package first

library(readr)   # Load the package
read_csv("data.csv")  # Now it works

title: R Handbook
text:
8.3 NA result

# Getting NA when calculating statistics

# CAUSE: Missing values in data
# FIX: Add na.rm = TRUE

mean(data$score)                 # Returns NA
mean(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)   # Returns the mean

title: R Handbook
text:
8.4 Unexpected symbol

# Error: unexpected symbol in...

# CAUSE: Usually a typo or missing comma/operator
# FIX: Check for:
#   - Missing commas between arguments
#   - Unclosed brackets or quotes
#   - Typos in function names

title: R Handbook
text:
8.5 Object of type closure

# Error: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable

# CAUSE: Using a function name as if it were data
# Common with: data$column (when 'data' is the function)

# FIX: Use a different variable name
my_data <- read_csv("file.csv")
my_data$column  # Works

title: R Handbook
text:
9.1 Complete Workflow Template

# 1. Load packages
library(readr)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

# 2. Load data
data <- read_csv("my_data.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

# 3. Inspect
head(data)
str(data)

# 4. Clean/transform
data <- data |>
  mutate(
    rev_item4 = 6 - item4,
    rev_item5 = 6 - item5,
    total = item1 + item2 + item3 + rev_item4 + rev_item5
  )

# 5. Summarise
summary_stats <- data |>
  group_by(condition, time) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(total, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(total, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# 6. Visualise
ggplot(data, aes(x = condition, y = total, fill = time)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "My Title", x = "Condition", y = "Score")

title: R Handbook
text:
9.2 Reporting Statistics in APA

# Get values
m <- mean(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
s <- sd(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
n <- sum(!is.na(data$score))

# Format for reporting
sprintf("M = %.2f, SD = %.2f", m, s)
# Output: "M = 3.45, SD = 0.89"

cat("Participants scored moderately (M =", round(m, 2), 
    ", SD =", round(s, 2), 
    ", n =", n, ")")

Run paired samples t-tests
Calculate and interpret Cohen’s d
Create comparison visualisations
Write APA-style results

# Assign a value to a variable

# View a variable
x
print(my_score)

# Remove a variable
rm(x)

# List all objects in environment
ls()

title: R Handbook
text:
2.2 Data Types

# Numeric
age <- 25
height <- 1.75

# Character (text)
name <- "Alice"
group <- "control"

# Logical (TRUE/FALSE)
passed <- TRUE
is_control <- FALSE

# Check type
class(age)        # "numeric"
class(name)       # "character"
class(passed)     # "logical"

title: R Handbook
text:
2.3 Vectors

# Create a vector with c()
scores <- c(4, 5, 3, 2, 5)
names <- c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol")
conditions <- c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE)

# Access elements
scores[1]         # First element: 4
scores[2:4]       # Elements 2 through 4
scores[c(1, 3)]   # Elements 1 and 3

# Useful functions
length(scores)    # Number of elements
sum(scores)       # Sum of all elements
mean(scores)      # Average
min(scores)       # Minimum
max(scores)       # Maximum

title: R Handbook
text:
2.4 Basic Operations

# Arithmetic
5 + 3     # Addition
10 - 4    # Subtraction
6 * 7     # Multiplication
20 / 4    # Division
2 ^ 3     # Exponent (2 cubed = 8)
17 %% 5   # Modulo (remainder: 2)

# Comparisons (return TRUE/FALSE)
5 > 3     # Greater than
5 < 3     # Less than
5 == 5    # Equal to
5 != 3    # Not equal to
5 >= 5    # Greater than or equal
5 <= 3    # Less than or equal

# Logical operators
TRUE & FALSE   # AND: FALSE
TRUE | FALSE   # OR: TRUE
!TRUE          # NOT: FALSE

title: R Handbook
text:
3.1 Loading Data

# From CSV (readr package - recommended)
library(readr)
data <- read_csv("filename.csv")
data <- read_csv("path/to/filename.csv")

# From CSV (base R)
data <- read.csv("filename.csv")

# From URL
data <- read_csv("https://example.com/data.csv")

# Suppress column type messages
data <- read_csv("filename.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

title: R Handbook
text:
3.2 Inspecting Data

# First/last rows
head(data)        # First 6 rows
head(data, 10)    # First 10 rows
tail(data)        # Last 6 rows

# Structure and dimensions
str(data)         # Structure with types
dim(data)         # Rows and columns
nrow(data)        # Number of rows
ncol(data)        # Number of columns

# Column names
names(data)       # All column names
colnames(data)    # Same as names()

# Summary statistics
summary(data)     # Summary of all columns

title: R Handbook
text:
3.3 Accessing Columns

# Using $ (most common)
data$age
data$group

# Using [[ ]]
data[["age"]]

# Using [ ] with column name
data[, "age"]

# Using [ ] with column number
data[, 1]         # First column
data[, 2:4]       # Columns 2 through 4

title: R Handbook
text:
3.4 Creating New Columns

# Simple calculation
data$new_column <- data$column1 + data$column2

# With conditions
data$category <- ifelse(data$score > 50, "high", "low")

# Multiple conditions
data$grade <- case_when(
  data$score >= 70 ~ "A",
  data$score >= 60 ~ "B",
  data$score >= 50 ~ "C",
  TRUE ~ "F"
)

title: R Handbook
text:
4.1 The Pipe Operator

library(dplyr)

# Pipe: |> (or %>%)
# Takes output from left, passes as first argument to right

# Without pipe
summarise(group_by(data, condition), mean = mean(score))

# With pipe (easier to read!)
data |>
  group_by(condition) |>
  summarise(mean = mean(score))

title: R Handbook
text:
4.2 Selecting Columns

# Select specific columns
data |> select(id, score, group)

# Select range of columns
data |> select(p1:p5)

# Remove columns
data |> select(-id, -notes)

# Select by pattern
data |> select(starts_with("p"))
data |> select(ends_with("score"))
data |> select(contains("time"))

title: R Handbook
text:
4.3 Filtering Rows

# Single condition
data |> filter(group == "control")
data |> filter(age > 25)

# Multiple conditions (AND)
data |> filter(group == "control", time == "pre")
data |> filter(group == "control" & time == "pre")

# Multiple conditions (OR)
data |> filter(group == "control" | group == "treatment")
data |> filter(group %in% c("control", "treatment"))

# Exclude missing values
data |> filter(!is.na(score))

title: R Handbook
text:
4.4 Creating/Modifying Columns

# Create new column
data |> mutate(total = p1 + p2 + p3)

# Modify existing column
data |> mutate(score = score / 100)

# Multiple operations
data |> mutate(
  total = p1 + p2 + p3,
  mean_score = total / 3,
  category = ifelse(total > 10, "high", "low")
)

title: R Handbook
text:
4.5 Grouping and Summarising

# Group by one variable
data |>
  group_by(condition) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n()
  )

# Group by multiple variables
data |>
  group_by(condition, time) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Count observations
data |> count(condition)
data |> count(condition, time)

title: R Handbook
text:
4.6 Arranging (Sorting)

# Sort ascending
data |> arrange(score)

# Sort descending
data |> arrange(desc(score))

# Sort by multiple columns
data |> arrange(group, desc(score))

title: R Handbook
text:
5.1 Central Tendency

# Mean
mean(data$score)
mean(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)  # Ignore missing values

# Median
median(data$score)
median(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Mode (no built-in function)
names(sort(table(data$category), decreasing = TRUE))[1]

title: R Handbook
text:
5.2 Variability

# Standard deviation
sd(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Variance
var(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Range
range(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
min(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
max(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Interquartile range
IQR(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

title: R Handbook
text:
5.3 Other Useful Statistics

# Sum
sum(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)

# Length/count
length(data$score)
n_distinct(data$id)  # Unique values (dplyr)

# Quantiles
quantile(data$score, probs = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75), na.rm = TRUE)

# Comprehensive summary
summary(data$score)

title: R Handbook
text:
6.1 Reverse Scoring

# For 1-5 scale: reversed = 6 - original
data$rev_item <- 6 - data$item

# For 1-7 scale: reversed = 8 - original
data$rev_item <- 8 - data$item

# For 0-4 scale: reversed = 4 - original
data$rev_item <- 4 - data$item

# General formula: reversed = (max + min) - original
# For 1-5: max + min = 6, so 6 - original

title: R Handbook
text:
6.2 Creating Scale Scores

# Sum score
data$total <- data$item1 + data$item2 + data$item3 + 
              data$rev_item4 + data$rev_item5

# Using rowSums (more efficient)
data$total <- rowSums(data[, c("item1", "item2", "item3", 
                                "rev_item4", "rev_item5")],
                      na.rm = TRUE)

# Mean score
data$mean_score <- rowMeans(data[, c("item1", "item2", "item3",
                                      "rev_item4", "rev_item5")],
                            na.rm = TRUE)

title: R Handbook
text:
7.1 Basic Structure

library(ggplot2)

# Basic template
ggplot(data, aes(x = variable1, y = variable2)) +
  geom_XXXXX() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Title", x = "X Label", y = "Y Label")

title: R Handbook
text:
7.2 Histogram

# Basic histogram
ggplot(data, aes(x = score)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30)

# Styled histogram
ggplot(data, aes(x = score)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, fill = "#4A90A4", colour = "white") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Scores", x = "Score", y = "Count")

# Histogram by group
ggplot(data, aes(x = score, fill = group)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, alpha = 0.6, position = "identity") +
  theme_minimal()

title: R Handbook
text:
7.3 Boxplot

# Basic boxplot
ggplot(data, aes(x = group, y = score)) +
  geom_boxplot()

# With fill colour
ggplot(data, aes(x = group, y = score, fill = group)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7)

# Grouped by two variables
ggplot(data, aes(x = group, y = score, fill = time)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Scores by Group and Time",
       x = "Group", y = "Score", fill = "Time")

title: R Handbook
text:
7.4 Bar Chart

# Counts
ggplot(data, aes(x = group)) +
  geom_bar()

# From summary data (means)
ggplot(summary_data, aes(x = group, y = mean)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#4A90A4") +
  theme_minimal()

# With error bars
ggplot(summary_data, aes(x = group, y = mean)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#4A90A4", alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = mean - se, ymax = mean + se), 
                width = 0.2) +
  theme_minimal()

title: R Handbook
text:
7.5 Scatterplot

# Basic scatterplot
ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = score)) +
  geom_point()

# With regression line
ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = score)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE) +
  theme_minimal()

# Coloured by group
ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = score, colour = group)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  theme_minimal()

title: R Handbook
text:
7.6 Customisation

# Themes
+ theme_minimal()
+ theme_classic()
+ theme_bw()

# Labels
+ labs(
    title = "Main Title",
    subtitle = "Subtitle",
    caption = "Data source",
    x = "X-axis Label",
    y = "Y-axis Label",
    fill = "Legend Title",
    colour = "Legend Title"
  )

# Colours
+ scale_fill_manual(values = c("control" = "#E8E8E8", 
                                "treatment" = "#4A90A4"))
+ scale_colour_manual(values = c("pre" = "#B8D4E3", 
                                  "post" = "#4A90A4"))

# Axis limits
+ xlim(0, 100)
+ ylim(0, 50)
+ coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 100), ylim = c(0, 50))

title: R Handbook
text:
8.1 Object not found

# Error: object 'x' not found

# CAUSE: Variable does not exist
# FIX: Create it first, or check spelling

x <- 5  # Create the object
x       # Now it works

title: R Handbook
text:
8.2 Could not find function

# Error: could not find function "read_csv"

# CAUSE: Package not loaded
# FIX: Load the package first

library(readr)   # Load the package
read_csv("data.csv")  # Now it works

title: R Handbook
text:
8.3 NA result

# Getting NA when calculating statistics

# CAUSE: Missing values in data
# FIX: Add na.rm = TRUE

mean(data$score)                 # Returns NA
mean(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)   # Returns the mean

title: R Handbook
text:
8.4 Unexpected symbol

# Error: unexpected symbol in...

# CAUSE: Usually a typo or missing comma/operator
# FIX: Check for:
#   - Missing commas between arguments
#   - Unclosed brackets or quotes
#   - Typos in function names

title: R Handbook
text:
8.5 Object of type closure

# Error: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable

# CAUSE: Using a function name as if it were data
# Common with: data$column (when 'data' is the function)

# FIX: Use a different variable name
my_data <- read_csv("file.csv")
my_data$column  # Works

title: R Handbook
text:
9.1 Complete Workflow Template

# 1. Load packages
library(readr)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

# 2. Load data
data <- read_csv("my_data.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

# 3. Inspect
head(data)
str(data)

# 4. Clean/transform
data <- data |>
  mutate(
    rev_item4 = 6 - item4,
    rev_item5 = 6 - item5,
    total = item1 + item2 + item3 + rev_item4 + rev_item5
  )

# 5. Summarise
summary_stats <- data |>
  group_by(condition, time) |>
  summarise(
    mean = mean(total, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd = sd(total, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# 6. Visualise
ggplot(data, aes(x = condition, y = total, fill = time)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "My Title", x = "Condition", y = "Score")

title: R Handbook
text:
9.2 Reporting Statistics in APA

# Get values
m <- mean(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
s <- sd(data$score, na.rm = TRUE)
n <- sum(!is.na(data$score))

# Format for reporting
sprintf("M = %.2f, SD = %.2f", m, s)
# Output: "M = 3.45, SD = 0.89"

cat("Participants scored moderately (M =", round(m, 2), 
    ", SD =", round(s, 2), 
    ", n =", n, ")")

title: Lab 2: Comparing Groups
text:
Lab 2 Preview
Week 2: Comparing Groups (t-tests)

title: Lab 2: Comparing Groups
text:
Today’s Lab Overview
Duration: 2 hours
Dataset: Experimental Data (n=120)
What we’ll do:

Independent samples t-test
Paired samples t-test
Effect sizes (Cohen’s d)
Reporting results in APA format

title: Lab 2: Comparing Groups
text:
Part 1: Independent Samples t-test
Time: 30 minutes
Compare two independent groups:
t.test(score ~ group, data = mydata)
When to use: Different participants in each condition

title: Lab 2: Comparing Groups
text:
Independent t-test: The Code
# Run the test
result <- t.test(score ~ condition, data = experiment)

# View results
result
Key output: - t-statistic - degrees of freedom - p-value - confidence interval

title: Lab 2: Comparing Groups
text:
Part 2: Paired Samples t-test
Time: 30 minutes
Compare repeated measures:
t.test(pre_score, post_score, paired = TRUE)
When to use: Same participants measured twice

title: Lab 2: Comparing Groups
text:
Paired t-test: The Code
# With two separate columns
t.test(data$pre, data$post, paired = TRUE)

# Or with long format data
t.test(score ~ time, data = long_data, paired = TRUE)

title: Lab 2: Comparing Groups
text:
Part 3: Effect Sizes
Time: 30 minutes
Calculate and interpret Cohen’s d:
library(effectsize)
cohens_d(score ~ group, data = mydata)



d value
Interpretation




0.2
Small


0.5
Medium


0.8
Large

title: Lab 2: Comparing Groups
text:
Part 4: APA Reporting
Time: 30 minutes
Write up results correctly:

There was a significant difference between groups, t(58) = 2.45, p = .017, d = 0.64, 95% CI [0.12, 1.16].

Include: - Test statistic and df - Exact p-value - Effect size with CI

title: Lab 2: Comparing Groups
text:
Key Takeaways
Today you learned to:

Run independent samples t-tests
Run paired samples t-tests
Calculate and interpret effect sizes
Report results in APA format
